title: Friday, 10th November, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:00am

Morning

PM11:01am

I'm back

PM11:01am

Back to help Bryce

11:01 am
PM11:01am

Rescue him perhaps?

PM11:01am

No.

PM11:01am

Disrupt?

11:01 am
PM11:01am

Maybe

PM11:01am

Get in the way?

PM11:01am

yes, for sure

11:01 am
PM11:01am

Let's get a pic up

PM11:02am

PM11:02am

That's from the Get Qatar slide deck, from David Rowland's firm. Allegedly

11:03 am
PM11:03am

Is it real? I'm assuming so, other wise the firm would have come straight out saying this is fake -- and stupid media has fallen for a stunt.

PM11:03am

But if it is real, it''s rather amateur hour

PM11:03am

"Control the yield curve, decide the future."

11:03 am
PM11:04am

Well...

BE11:04am

David .............. Rowland's ............... Qatar slide deck?

BE11:04am

Cripes. Those are words I didn't expect to see in the same sentence.

11:04 am
PM11:04am

Oh, I didn't explain!

PM11:04am

Assuming everyone's looked at it

PM11:04am

Here https://theinterce...villand-world-cup/

11:04 am
PM11:05am

Another screen grab

PM11:05am

BE11:05am

My word.

11:05 am
PM11:06am

There's lots more via that link above

BE11:06am

I mean, you have to wonder if anyone at any point just Googled Spotty.

BE11:06am

I mean, https://www.ft.com...-8526-7b38dcaef614

11:07 am
PM11:07am

Yeah, I know

PM11:08am

Anyway, you can read all that later

undefined
11:08 am
PM11:08am

You had loads of corporate yesterday

PM11:08am

And today...

PM11:08am

Rather less

11:08 am
BE11:08am

Yeah, there's zip. It's dull.

PM11:09am

Footsie drifting

PM11:09am

Off 17 points or so

11:09 am
BE11:09am

Yeah, only by a tad, down 0.2%. With Bunzl leading us backwards.

Bunzl PLC (BNZL:LSE): Last: 2,170, down 138 (-5.98%), High: 2,311, Low: 2,158, Volume: 733.81k
BE11:10am

And I know how the ROTR like their paper and packaging, or packaging and paper .... I forget which order Bunzl wants us to put them in.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

So the upshot here is that Morgan Stanley thinks box making's going to get Amazon-d.

PM11:11am

How so?

BE11:12am

Well, I should point out that it's a 47 page note that has seven bylines, all of whom get a bubble pic.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

BE11:13am

That's where your MifidII fees are going. Seven folk to tell you that Amazon going into B2B distribution is probably not great for the incumbents.

BE11:13am

There is an increasing focus on the B2B distribution business being developed under the Amazon Business (covered by Brian
Nowak) brand name, with revenues of ~$1bn growing at ~20%. The platform was introduced in 2012 as Amazon Supply with a
rebrand in 2015, which resulted in a spike in search volumes. The target distribution verticals are fairly broad including
pharmaceuticals, foodservice, industrial and office supplies (see Foodservice, Pharmaceutical, and Industrial Distributors: Who’s
Exposed to Amazon?). As a result, the disruption caused by Amazon Business has become a key debate for some stocks,
including Bunzl and Rexel.
We think minimal downside risk has been priced into Bunzl, whereas Rexel lost 27% of its value between May and September,
after concerns emerged its business model and financials could be impacted by Amazon Business. This was potentially
exacerbated by the poor performance at Grainger (covered by Nigel Coe), which was largely attributed to the Amazon threat.
We see here an important market disconnect in terms of perception, as our proprietary analysis suggests that the Bunzl
business model is potentially more susceptible to early stage disruption compared to Rexel. We think this presents investors
with an opportunity to switch from Underweight rated Bunzl to Overweight rated Rexel.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

And it all references back to Morgan Stanleys BRAIN framework, which is a big model thing about who's going to get Amazon'd and who isn't.

BE11:15am

PM11:15am

Does BRIAN stand for something?

11:16 am
BE11:16am

I was wondering that. Don't think it's an acronym, but I have to admit to not reading all 47 pages.

PM11:16am

Oh yes i see, how i have right clicked

BE11:16am

Did I say Brain? I meant Brian of course.

11:16 am
PM11:17am

Bespoke products, regulatory hurdles and so on

BE11:17am

Super. Anyway ..................... From there, we set off for a long journey around purchasing frequency and customer order complexity in the cardboard box market.

BE11:18am

Case studies on books, of course, along with the LED lighting market. Once you get through all that you get to the idea that Bunzl's quite expensive.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

n our view, fundamentals drive the historical valuation differential, with Bunzl trading at an average premium of +38% vs. Rexel
over the last 10 years. The premium has been justified by a more resilient performance at Bunzl and should be maintained to
some extent going forward. However, because of the higher susceptibility to early stage Amazon disruption at Bunzl, which is
not yet priced in, we would anticipate a decline in the average premium through time. Our estimates of previous episodes of
disruption suggests multiples compress by -31% as the market prices in an erosion of competitive advantage before numbers
fall - Rexel EV/EBITA multiple has fallen ~10% since the spring of 2017 whereas Bunzl is -5.3%.

BE11:19am

So, there we go. Bunzl's quite expensive. But if you want a better reason to tell your clients, there's BRIAN, or indeed BRAIN.

undefined
11:19 am
BE11:20am

Following behind Bunzl we have Burberry .....

Burberry Group PLC (BRBY:LSE): Last: 1,728, down 59 (-3.30%), High: 1,780, Low: 1,711, Volume: 2.01m
BE11:20am

Downgrades coming through post yesterday's warning.

11:20 am
PM11:20am

I thought you'd be Burberried out

PM11:20am

But go on

BE11:21am

I am. The sellside ain't.

11:20 am
BE11:21am

Bernstein, for example.

BE11:21am

The company's new CEO Marco Gobbetti has now defined a clear brand strategy to elevate the long-term positioning for the brand. However, we believe there is significant execution risk and that the management guidance of flat revenues and margins for FY18 and FY19 as too optimistic. We believe Burberry has the potential to emerge as the next big thing, but in the meantime shares will be suppressed as investors await further news regarding the hiring of a new creative director and progress in the brand transformation which will require time and short-term sacrifice (eg. cut of wholesale doors etc). We believe the stock will continue to be pressured in the coming months and thereby downgrade to Underperform. We reduce our target price to £14,00 (old £16.00).

BE11:22am

And also UBS.

11:21 am
BE11:22am

Burberry has been our preferred turnaround name in European luxury given the opportunity to structurally improve sales densities, drive cost efficiencies, and run a more efficient capital structure. The strategic update unveiled by the new CEO suggests that the long term opportunity to improve sales densities remains via reshaping product, upgrading distribution, and focusing on digital. However, the costs (both opex and capex) to do this will be higher, and for longer, than we expected: we cut FY19e EBIT 12% and FY20e 17%. The payback of this investment will be improving like-for-like ('LFL') growth, but visibility is limited here with no Creative Director even yet announced. For now, our forecasts reflect 4% EBIT CAGR and 6% EPS CAGR to FY22e, vs. a valuation of 21.9x cal 2018e P/E. We see balanced risk/reward and downgrade to Neutral with our new 12 month price target £18.00.

BE11:23am

Though a better Friday read, from Mario Ortelli at Bernstein, is a piece about luxury brands trying to hop into bed with streetwear.

BE11:24am

It doesn't include this picture, but probably should.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

BE11:25am

So, we have Burberry x Gosha Rubchinskiy .....

BE11:25am

Founder of his namesake brand and a photographer, Gosha
Rubchunskiy emerged onto the fashion scene with collections
inspired by Russia's streets, youth culture and the fall of the Iron
Curtain. In his latest 2018 Spring/Summer collection in St.
Petersbury, Gosha revealed this work with Burberry, inspired by
football and Russia rave aesthetics. The collection included
Burberry's trademark trench coat cut up into two colours, as well
T-shirts and shorts in Burberry's signature check print (Exhibits
18, 19). The entire collection will be available on Burberry's
ecommerce website in Jan 2018.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Which looks like this.

BE11:26am

BE11:27am

According to Bernstein, this type of collaboration "paints a clear picture of the millennial luxury consumer – one who is daring to express and pamper himself, and seeks products which can convey his distinct tastes and attitude. Luxury streetwear, which in most cases are limited edition capsule collections, ticks all the boxes. Whats more, luxury streetwear creates buzz for brands which attracts consumers of all age groups."

11:27 am
BE11:27am

And according to me, it underlines the stuff I was waffling on yesterday about the identity crisis in the lux sector.

BE11:27am

But, hey, what do I know.

undefined
11:28 am
BE11:28am

Oh, and while we're recapping previous sessions ......

BE11:29am

Interested to see Jim Cramer tip Palo Alto Networks overnight.

PM11:29am

Id missed this

11:30 am
BE11:30am

It was part of a wrap of cybersecurity stocks, and was mostly just the usual CNBC background shouting, but still quite interesting to see the name pop up.

BE11:31am

Regular readers will remember that Neil Hume flagged the recent gossip around Palo Alto, which folk seem to think is looking a bit vulnerable to sector interest.

PM11:31am

hmm

11:31 am
BE11:31am

There's also, I note in passing, a Piper note out overnight making relatively reassuring noises about demand.

BE11:31am

We recently conducted another round of channel checks with a subset of Palo Alto resellers that contribute to our normal quarterly survey. The overall feedback suggests market demand is depressed, particularly from the large enterprise customers. However, we do not believe this represents much of a change from calendar Q3 to Q4, and therefore, we believe this is already factored into management’s guidance. We also note that the company has easy comparisons for both product revenue and billings in FQ2(Jan) and FQ3(Apr), suggesting guidance should be in line with Street expectations. Looking beyond the next few quarters, we believe Palo Alto’s new operating system and new appliances will drive a sustainable refresh cycle in calendar 2018 and beyond. Therefore, we reiterate an Overweight rating and $155 PT.

PM11:01am

Welcome to Markets Live

11:31 am
BE11:32am

BE11:32am

Anyway, just noting as one to keep an eye on. No new info.

undefined
11:33 am
BE11:33am

While on tech, should probably mention IQE

IQE PLC (IQE:LSE): Last: 162.00, up 22 (+15.71%), High: 166.25, Low: 152.00, Volume: 19.02m
PM11:34am

Raised £95m i see

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Cashbox at 140p.

BE11:34am

67.9m shares, 9.9% of float. Canaccord, Stifel and Peel Hunt as bookrunners.

BE11:35am

Cash will be used for “multiple high growth mass market opportunities”, which sounds awfully exciting.

11:35 am
PM11:36am

This thing has had an extraordinary run over the past 18 months

BE11:36am

In part on the iPhone's depth sensing camera thing

BE11:37am

Which we had a stab at explaining here, and I won't revisit: https://ftalphavil...tslive/2017-09-13/

11:37 am
BE11:38am

So anyway, the IQE placing wasn't entirely out of the blue after Stifel mailed this out yesterday ..................

BE11:38am

We are unable to distribute research on IQE (IQE.LN) due to a research restriction. As such we cannot make further research generally available on our research library. Prior research, including estimates and rating, accessible on our research library, is not held out as applicable after the date of its issue. Please refer to public sources for company regulatory announcements, or the company’s own website for further information.

PM11:38am

hehehe

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Luckily, Citi steps into the breach today with a rather long initiation note.

BE11:39am

It's packed full of explainers .....

BE11:39am

11:40 am
BE11:40am

And guys in hazmat suits who are doing serious things and looking serious.

BE11:40am

BE11:41am

And .... more explainers!

11:40 am
BE11:41am

BE11:42am

I get the feeling that they could've put a few pages of Moby Dick in around the 30 page mark, just as a test to see if any fund manager actually made it that far.

BE11:42am

Anyway, let's cut up to the summary.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

IQE is a global supplier of advanced wafer products and services to the semiconductor industry. IQE shares have outperformed the EU Tech/UK SMID indices by ~320/~340 pts over the past year, reflecting growing appreciation of the firm’s unique positioning in the compound semiconductor value chain. However, we see more upside for the shares driven by the wider 3D sensing opportunity in smartphones, resilient business model & scope for margin expansion.

BE11:43am

So, IQE's VCSEL epitaxial wafer is the next smartphone must have, says Citi .....

BE11:43am

Over CY17-20E, we estimate a CAGR of ~100% for the VCSEL business, driving ~80% CAGR for Photonics sales. With Wireless unit (~69% CY16 sales) steady, we see ~30% CAGR for group revenue over CY17-20E.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

And no chance of commoditisation.

BE11:44am

In contrast to manufacturing of mainstream silicon wafers, the technological complexity, as well as bespoke nature of the compound semiconductor epitaxy process structurally implies lower risk of commoditization in our view. Further, IQE is even better positioned in our view thanks to a broad portfolio of technologies, early-mover advantage and global manufacturing footprint.

BE11:44am

Plus, margins!

11:44 am
BE11:44am

In addition to top line leverage, we also see scope for margin
expansion driven by three cost base transformation levers: improving product mix, rationalization of support functions and manufacturing efficiencies. We therefore model GM adjusted OPM expansion of ~630~710 bps over the period CY17-20E.

BE11:45am

Therefore, stick it on 28 times.

BE11:45am

We value IQE on a PE basis to best capture both earnings momentum and visibility. We arrive at the target 28x multiple by applying a PEG ratio of 0.7x to our base case 40% CY17-20E EPS CAGR, driving a TP of 195p using CY19E EPS. Our bull/bear case drives upside/downside to 250p/100p.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

That's the gist of that.

undefined
PM11:46am

What the hell is going on at LSE?

11:45 am
BE11:46am

Ugh.

PM11:46am

I see the TCI has called a shareholder meeting

PM11:46am

And now want to sack Brydon as chairman and retainXavier Rolet

11:46 am
PM11:46am

I don't quite understand what is going on here

BE11:47am

Ditto. Story here: https://www.ft.com...-b2bb-322b2cb39656

PM11:47am

Hohn has just said Rolet was being forced out

11:47 am
PM11:47am

But nothing more

PM11:47am

And the LSE havent said anything at all.

PM11:48am

I think we mentioned that the statement looked odd -- on Rolet's departure -- when it first came out

11:48 am
BE11:48am

It all seems rather personal and niggly in a way that, to me at least, doesn't seem to connect in an obvious way to shareholder value.

BE11:49am

But perhaps there's an angle around sector consolidation or something that I'm failing to see.

PM11:49am

Very odd. PR disaster

11:49 am
London Stock Exchange Group PLC (LSE:LSE): Last: 3,745, up 12 (+0.32%), High: 3,759, Low: 3,737, Volume: 76.46k
PM11:50am

Surprised the stock has held up as well as it has

BE11:50am

Hm. So I get the TCI argument about clarity, but I also understand that Rolet had planned to step down after the completion of the DB1-LSE deal (had that happened.)

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Transparency about why he exited would be no bad thing. I'm not entirely sure that Mr Hohn's approach will deliver transparency. An armadillo type response seems more likely.

undefined
BE11:52am

Oh, speaking of the sector, did you see ICAP's broken?

11:52 am
BE11:52am

Or was, last night.

PM11:52am

No i didn't

BE11:52am

Network outage.

11:52 am
BE11:52am

https://www.ft.com...-a40f-b21bed810045

BE11:54am

Which in itself isn't terribly significant, but it does all add to the general feeling that the IDB sector's a bit embattled right now.

BE11:55am

You've got NEX Group as well, which seems to be toiling a bit.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

Put together with the LSE stramash, I'd not be surprised to see a theme reviving of defensive consolidation and suchlike.

undefined
PM11:57am

What have we missed?

11:57 am
PM11:57am

https://twitter.com/muddywatersre/status/928768147762614272

PM11:58am

What that tweet needed to add was to say "on no obvious news"

BE11:58am

I generally dislike talking in stock tickers. I particularly dislike talking in Hong Kong stock tickers.

11:58 am
BE11:59am

So, Google tells me that's Li Bao Ge Group Ltd.

BE11:59am

Cayman Islands registered Chinese restaurant operator.

BE12:00pm

Brands include Star of Canton and Beijing House. Apparently.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

Uh ...........

BE12:01pm

As of December 31, 2016, the company had four full-service restaurants in Hong Kong and a full-service restaurant in Shenzhen to provide Cantonese cuisine and Chinese banquet, and dining services.

BE12:01pm

Five restaurants, doing Chinese food in HK and China. $1bn market cap?

12:01 pm
BE12:02pm

That looks normal.

PM12:02pm

hehehe

undefined
12:03 pm
PM12:03pm

Look at the time

PM12:03pm

I think we are done

BE12:03pm

Thumbs up

12:03 pm
PM12:03pm

Thank you Bryce!

PM12:03pm

And cheers for joining on the right

PM12:03pm

Back tomorrow at 11am

12:03 pm
PM12:03pm

Bye

BE12:03pm

NOT BACK TOMORROW!

BE12:04pm

I refuse! I'm painting living room.

12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

Back Monday. Afternoon all.

BE12:05pm

(@wayneJ: no offence, but I wouldn't let most of you lot in my house.)

BE11:32am

Which also has a valuation chart to highlight that Palo's quite cheap.
